**Report Generated:** January 26, 2026  
**Next Refresh:** April 27, 2026

**Disclaimer:** This sell-side report was generated using Claude Sonnet 4 (claude-sonnet-4-20250514). Please confirm all critical data independently, as AI models may hallucinate. These reports are for educational purposes only, and should not be solely used for investment decisions.

---

# 1. Company Overview (USFD) - Comprehensive Analysis Report

## 1. Company Overview

US Foods Holding Corp. is the second-largest food service distributor in the U.S., after Sysco. The company supplies 250,000 locations including independent restaurants, chain restaurants, healthcare, hospitality, and educational institutions. US Foods has trailing twelve-month revenue of over $39.11 billion in 2025 and as of late 2025, the company's market capitalization stood at approximately $16.4 billion, with about 223 million shares outstanding. 

In 2024, 34% of revenues came from meats and seafoods, 17% of revenues came from dry grocery products, 17% of revenue came from refrigerated and frozen grocery products, 11% of revenues came from dairy, 9% of revenues came from supplies, 6% of revenues came from produce, and 6% of revenues came from beverages. US Foods Holding Corp. operates as a critical, high-volume link between over 6,000 suppliers and more than 300,000 customer locations across the United States, primarily by managing a complex, national supply chain to deliver food and business solutions. The company is ranked 122nd on the Fortune 500 and 1127th on the Forbes Global 2000.

## 2. Current Market Data

During the trading session on 2026-01-24, US Foods(USFD) shares reached a daily high of $81.85 and a low of $80.88. At a current price of $81.27, the stock is +0.5% higher than the low and still -0.7% under the high. The stock's 52-week range extends from a low of $57.36 to a high of $85.85. USFD reached its all-time high on Jan 16, 2026 with the price of 85.85 USD, and its all-time low was 8.32 USD and was reached on Mar 18, 2020. The current market capitalization of US Foods Holding is $16.4B. Its current market cap is $16.4B with 223M shares. USFD doesn't pay any dividends to its shareholders.

## 3. Existing Products/Services

The company generates revenue by efficiently sourcing, stocking, and distributing over 400,000 products, focusing on high-margin growth in the independent restaurant segment. The company's offerings span a vast array of food and non-food items, but its higher-margin Exclusive Brands and digital tools are what truly differentiate its value proposition for operators. 

The company's product offerings include meat, seafood, refrigerated, frozen, and dry grocery products, dairy products, beverages, and other produce. It markets and sells these products under various brands such as Chef's Line, Stock Yards, Metro Deli, Harvest Value, Monarch, Monogram, Molly's Kitchen, and Glenview Farms. The company through its retail outlets Chef'Stores, Food Fanatics, and Smart Foodservice distributes foodservice equipment and supplies.

US Foods differentiates itself through its comprehensive service model, combining broad product selection with value-added services such as culinary support, menu development, and business consulting.

## 4. Planned Products/Services/Projects

A centerpiece of that effort is MOXē, US Foods' ecommerce platform. The company introduced an AI-powered search tool this year that Flitman said is "already delivering measurable results." Customers are locating products faster, and the feature is generating more complete orders equivalent to roughly 1.3 million additional cases annually.

US Foods is pairing those digital gains with new distribution models. The company expects its Pronto small-truck delivery service — designed for tighter routes and faster turnaround — to generate about $950 million in sales this year and exceed a $1 billion annual run rate by year-end.

The company announced a move to a 100% variable compensation plan for local sellers to further accelerate growth, with piloting underway and full rollout planned for 2026.

## 5. Growth Strategy

US Foods announced today that it is reaffirming its fiscal year 2025 guidance and 2025 to 2027 long-range plan growth algorithm. "This performance underscores the consistent execution of our strategy and positions us well for sustained profitable growth for many years to come. I remain highly confident that we will achieve our long-range plan growth algorithm of 5% Net sales CAGR, a 10% Adjusted EBITDA CAGR and a 20% Adjusted Diluted EPS CAGR through 2027."

Since going public, US Foods has focused on organic growth initiatives, technology investments, and strategic acquisitions to strengthen its market position. The company has invested heavily in supply chain automation, e-commerce platforms, and data analytics capabilities to improve operational efficiency and customer service. US Foods has also expanded its private label portfolio and enhanced its value-added services to differentiate itself from competitors and drive customer loyalty.

AI is also transforming how the company moves goods. A rollout of Descartes routing software across its national network improved delivery efficiency by 2.3% compared with last year, while the operations quality initiative cut order errors by 24%. Chief financial officer Dirk Locascio said AI now touches nearly every part of the business. "We're using it to recommend products online, build order guides for sellers in minutes instead of hours, and give customers accurate delivery updates," he said.

## 6. Current and Potential Major Clients

Its customers include independently owned single and multi-unit restaurants, regional concepts, national restaurant chains, hospitals, nursing homes, hotels and motels, country clubs, government and military organizations, colleges and universities, and retail locations.

On January 8, 2026, TheFly reported that the Defense Logistics Agency had awarded US Foods Holding Corp. (NYSE:USFD) a maximum $198.26 million firm-fixed-price contract with economic price adjustment. The indefinite-delivery, indefinite-quantity contract covers a full line of food and beverage products and was awarded as a sole-source purchase under 10 U.S. Code 3204 and FAR 6.302-1. US Foods, Port Orange, Florida, has been awarded a maximum $544,460,000 fixed-price with economic-price-adjustment, indefinite-quantity contract for full-line food distribution.

## 7. Financial Data & Performance

US Foods reported third quarter fiscal 2025 highlights: Grew Net Sales 4.8% to $10.2 Billion, Net Income 3.4% to $153 Million and Diluted EPS 9.8% to $0.67. Grew Adjusted EBITDA 11.0% to $505 Million and Adjusted Diluted EPS 25.9% to $1.07. Total case volume increased 1.1%; independent restaurant case volume increased 3.9%. Net sales increased 4.8% to $10.2 billion. Gross profit increased 5.2% to $1.8 billion. Net income increased 3.4% to $153 million. Adjusted EBITDA increased 11.0% to $505 million. Diluted EPS increased 9.8% to $0.67; Adjusted Diluted EPS increased 25.9% to $1.07.

US Foods's EPS grew at a solid 39.7% compounded annual growth rate over the last five years, higher than its 10.6% annualized revenue growth. This tells us the company became more profitable on a per-share basis as it expanded. In Q3, US Foods reported adjusted EPS of $1.07, up from $0.85 in the same quarter last year. This print beat analysts' estimates by 3.7%. Over the next 12 months, Wall Street expects US Foods's full-year EPS of $3.78 to grow 18%.

The trailing twelve month revenue for US Foods Holding is $39.1B. US Foods Holding's EPS for 12 months was $2.36. EBITDA measures a company's operating performance, its growth signifies an improvement in the efficiency of a company. US Foods Holding Corp. EBITDA is ‪1.80 B‬ USD, and current EBITDA margin is 4.33%.

## 8. Headwinds & Tailwinds

### Headwinds:
US Foods's recent performance shows its demand has slowed as its annualized revenue growth of 5.5% over the last two years was below its five-year trend. The industry faces ongoing pressure from alternative distribution models including direct-from-manufacturer sales, online marketplaces, and specialty distributors focusing on organic, local, or ethnic foods.

Economic factors affecting consumer confidence and discretionary spending and reducing the consumption of food prepared away from home; cost inflation/deflation and commodity volatility; competition; reliance on third party suppliers and interruption of product supply or increases in product costs.

### Tailwinds:
US Foods posted robust third quarter results with 4.8% net sales growth and an 11% increase in adjusted EBITDA. US Foods continued to outpace the market, achieving 3.9% independent restaurant case growth and its 18th consecutive quarter of share gains in this segment. Margin improvement was driven by gross profit initiatives, productivity, and cost savings, including $120 million in expected strategic vendor savings for 2025.

Through the first nine months of 2025, US Foods sales increased 4.4% to $29.4 billion. In that period, net income rose 16.8% to $432 million. The growth reflects stronger productivity and continued share gains with independent restaurants.

## 9. Market Shares

Performance Food Group is the third largest foodservice distribution company in North America, behind Sysco and US Foods, which all together command approximately 38% market share. More broadly, the deal would create the largest foodservice distributor in the U.S.: Bloomberg cites 18% market share for the combined company, against 17% for Sysco. (Those figures seem to match those detailed by Sysco itself last year.)

Sysco has long held the crown in the US foodservice distribution world, boasting a sturdy 17% market share. Sysco, the longtime leader with ~23% market share, has seen its dominance challenged as competitors like PFG and USFD grow through acquisitions.

## 10. Comparison to Competitors

Performance Food Group, United Natural Foods, The Chefs' Warehouse, Sysco, and SpartanNash are some of the 26 competitors of US Foods Holding. The combined market capitalization would have been north of $30 billion, rivaling the largest food distributor, Houston-based Sysco (NYSE: SYY), which has a $36 billion market cap.

USFD: At $72/share (July 2025), it trades at 10x 2025E EBITDA, below Sysco's 12x multiple. PFGC: At $85/share, it's undervalued at 14.2x forward P/E, vs. Sysco's 18.5x.

In 2024, Sysco commanded a substantial 17% market share within the U.S. foodservice distribution sector. For fiscal year 2025, Sysco reported net sales amounting to $81.4 billion. US Foods is another major competitor, demonstrating robust performance with net sales of $37.9 billion in fiscal year 2024 and continued market share expansion in Q1 2025.

## 11. Partnerships, Mergers and Acquisitions

Repurchased ~$335 Million of Shares Signed Definitive Agreement to Acquire Shetakis. Subsequent to quarter-end, the Company has signed a definitive agreement to acquire Shetakis, an independent food distributor located in Las Vegas, Nevada. The Company is targeting to close the transaction in the fourth quarter of 2025.

US Foods and Performance Food Group ended their merger discussions after a thorough evaluation of regulatory considerations and potential synergies. The companies had been exploring this merger for approximately three months before deciding not to proceed.

Merger Talks Termination: US Foods has ended its merger discussions with Performance Food Group, with CEO Dave Flitman stating that the board concluded independent operations are more beneficial for long-term value creation, emphasizing clarity in the company's strategic direction.

## 12. Recent Developments

**January 2026:**
- On January 8, 2026, TheFly reported that the Defense Logistics Agency had awarded US Foods Holding Corp. (NYSE:USFD) a maximum $198.26 million firm-fixed-price contract with economic price adjustment
- USFD has reaffirmed its fiscal year 2025 guidance that was previously announced during its third quarter earnings call on November 6, 2025. The foodservice distributor maintained its outlook for net sales growth of 4% to 5%, adjusted EBITDA growth of 10% to 12%, and adjusted diluted EPS growth of 24% to 26% for the fiscal year.
- Share Repurchase Plan: US Foods plans a $250 million accelerated share repurchase agreement and has authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase, demonstrating confidence in its own value and aiming to enhance shareholder returns.

**Q3 2025 Results:**
- Net sales increased 4.8% to $10.2 billion. Gross profit increased 5.2% to $1.8 billion. Net income increased 3.4% to $153 million. Adjusted EBITDA increased 11.0% to $505 million.
- Management confidence is underscored by a robust share repurchase program, with approximately $335 million of shares bought back in Q3 2025 alone.

## 13. AI Investment Rating & Fair Value Assessment

Based on comprehensive analysis of US Foods' financial performance, market position, and growth trajectory:

**Positive Factors:**
- Consistent market share gains with 18 consecutive quarters of independent restaurant growth
- Strong margin expansion driven by operational efficiency initiatives and AI implementation  
- Robust financial metrics: 39.7% EPS CAGR over 5 years, 11% adjusted EBITDA growth in Q3
- According to 11 analysts, the average rating for USFD stock is "Strong Buy." The 12-month stock price target is $88.36, which is an increase of 15.14% from the latest price.
- Major defense contract wins providing stable government revenue
- Aggressive capital return strategy with $1 billion share repurchase authorization

**Risk Factors:**
- Industry-wide softness in foodservice demand
- High valuation multiples relative to growth rates
- Commodity price volatility and inflation pressures
- Competitive pressure from alternative distribution models

**Buy Rating: 7.8/10**

This "Strong Buy" rating reflects USFD's solid fundamentals, consistent execution, market-leading position in independent restaurant segment, and strong margin expansion capabilities. The company's AI-driven operational improvements and robust cash generation support sustainable growth.

**Fair Value Estimate: $92-95**

Based on:
- Forward P/E multiple of 18-19x applied to 2026E EPS of $5.00-5.25
- EV/EBITDA multiple of 11-12x applied to 2026E EBITDA of $2.0-2.1 billion
- DCF valuation assuming 5-6% revenue CAGR and margin expansion through 2027

The current trading range of $80-85 suggests 15-18% upside to fair value, making USFD attractive for growth-oriented portfolios seeking exposure to the recovering foodservice industry with moderate risk tolerance.
tldr_summary:
US Foods Holding Corp. is the second-largest food service distributor in the U.S., supplying over 250,000 locations with food and related products across various sectors including restaurants, healthcare, and educational institutions.

Key investment considerations include their strategic focus on digital transformation through MOXē e-commerce platform and AI-powered tools, consistent market share gains in independent restaurants, and robust financial performance with 39.7% EPS CAGR over five years. The company is aggressively expanding delivery capabilities, notably with its Pronto small-truck service expected to generate $1 billion annually. Despite industry headwinds, US Foods has maintained strong operational efficiency, secured significant government contracts (including a $198 million Defense Logistics Agency award), and demonstrated ability to navigate commodity price volatility through strategic vendor savings and productivity initiatives.

With an AI buy rating of 7.8/10 and a fair value estimate of $92-95, USFD represents an attractive investment opportunity with approximately 15-18% potential upside in the recovering foodservice market.
